The Cross - Ancient Egyptian  :

In ancient Egyptian religions, the cross symbolized the four elements of nature and their corresponding deities. The cross, or more specifically the ankh, was a symbol of life and immortality and represented the concept of balance and harmony, which was highly valued in Egyptian culture.

Each arm of the cross was associated with a different element, with the horizontal arm representing the earthly realm, and the vertical arm representing the spiritual realm. The intersection of the arms represented the joining of these two realms and the balance between them.

The ankh was also associated with the concept of regeneration and eternal life, as it was believed to have the power to bestow life and immortality on those who possessed it. This made it a highly prized symbol, and it was commonly used in Egyptian art and religious iconography.
In Phoenician culture, the cross was also used as a symbol of the goddess Astarte, who was associated with fertility and sexuality. The Phoenicians, like the Egyptians, believed that the cross symbolized the balance between the earthly and spiritual realms, and they saw it as a representation of the divine in the natural world.

Overall, the cross had spiritual significance in both ancient Egyptian and Phoenician cultures. While the specific meanings attributed to the symbol varied between cultures and regions, the cross was generally seen as a symbol of balance, harmony, regeneration, and the divine in the natural world.   The Cross - Ancient Phoenicians   In Phoenician religion, the goddess Astarte was one of the most prominent deities, and was associated with fertility, sexuality, and love. She was also believed to have the power to bestow prosperity, wealth, and good fortune to those who worshipped her.

The cross symbol was closely linked to Astarte, and was used as a representation of her divine powers. It was believed that the cross symbolized the four directions of the world, and that Astarte had the power to bestow blessings and fertility upon the earth.
The cross symbol was often used in religious iconography, including in the decoration of temples, altars, and other sacred spaces. It was also incorporated into jewelry and other objects of personal adornment, as well as into everyday objects such as pottery and textiles.
In addition to its association with Astarte, the cross symbol was also seen as representing the balance and harmony of the natural world. It was believed that the cross symbolized the four elements of earth, air, fire, and water, and that Astarte had the power to control these elements and ensure their balance and harmony.

Overall, the cross symbol played an important role in Phoenician religion, representing the power and influence of the goddess Astarte, as well as the balance and harmony of the natural world. Its significance can still be seen in various religious traditions and practices today.
